content:
This works for release 128.

This is the official (to my knowledge) documentation. Well worth the read https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

Here is my own documentation on threading, duplicating the above, but it may help: You need to highlight each folder and click View>sort by>unthreaded. If this applies to just a few folders, just repeat the process as necessary. If you have many folders or plan to add many new folders, you may wish a different approach, below:

FOR NEW FOLDERS To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: mailnews.default_view_flags 0 =unthreaded

Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom right. 

 ------------

FOR EXISTING FOLDERS These steps may help: To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: This must be done on an account by account basis.

  1. select table view - the icon just to right of 'quick filter' button above message list pane
  2. select a message folder and apply all desired attributes - View>sort by from menu bar (if not shown, click alt key)
  3. click the icon at right side of column display in message list pane
  4. select the entry near bottom 'Apply current view to...'
  5. highlight 'folder and children'
  6. move mouse left to see account name and move left again to display all account folders. Now CLICK. a small menu will appear to confirm setting all folders within that account.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thunderbird is an email client program which you download and install from this link:

  • https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Thunderbird is not a server. It does not provide new email addresses.

Email addresses can be provided by your Internet Service Provider or maybe you have a domain and website which also provides email addresses or maybe you have paid for an email address or obtained a free one from eg: gmail.

If you already have an existing email address, you can create a mail account in Thunderbird to access the server which receives your emails. It means you do not have to logon via webmail using a browser to see emails. If you have more than one email address with same or different servers then you can create several mail accounts and therefore be able to see all emails from all email accounts in one view. You can create Pop and/or Imap mail accounts. Using Thunderbird, you can read and send emails and it also has a built in calendar. You can also link up to other calendars eg: google/gmail. It has Address Books and many features etc. You can also create and link to feed accounts, chat accounts and newsgroup acounts.

After installing Thunderbird you can create a mail account for an exisiting email address. The first time you run Thunderbird, it usually prompts you to set up a mail account, but if you did not do it at that a time you can clickon the 'Menu app icon (3 lines)' select 'New Account' and select 'Email' Follow instructions. Please note: Some servers require additional measures to set connection. Some servers do not acept normal password and require you to create a 'secure app password'/'app generated password', others will need you to set up 'Authentication Method 'Oauth' eg: gmail, so you may need to ask what additional steps should be taken to ensure a proper connection. Xfinity requires you to logon to webmail and make sure you have set up the account to allow third party access.

You will need to provide a lot more information about the server you want to connect to because I could go on guessing forever and that's a waste both of our time.

There are many Help Articles which you can use, but sometimes you might find they are bit out date as Thunderbird has undergone alot of recent changes.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: Yu5tiqX9og

content:
Just to clear things up: you don’t actually need to donate to download Thunderbird — it’s completely free and open source. The donation page is just Mozilla’s way of asking for optional support, but it shouldn’t block the download.

Here’s how you can get it directly:

Go to the official Thunderbird site: https://www.thunderbird.net/download

Click Free Download — it should start right away without asking for payment.

If it keeps looping you back to the donation page, try opening the link in a private/incognito window, or clear your browser cache and cookies, then retry.

Once downloaded, you can install and start using Thunderbird with no restrictions.

content:
If the accounts are IMAP, these steps will set it right: Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

If the accounts are POP, then more information in the details are needed, such as that there were already messages there, and that there are thousands of messages in wrong folders.

content: I presume you transferred with a USB stick or similar? Open that device with Windows File Explorer. Then, locate the thunderbird folder Open the profiles.ini (text file) to confirm profile's name Now, click to the thunderbird\profiles folder and open that profile Next, click the Mail folder You should now see the POP account name Then, click that to see the folders for the account. You should see all the folders for the account that were visible under the account from within Thunderbird on old PC. Are the files there (e.g., inbox, inbox.msf, sent, sent.msf, etc) Can you do a screenshot of the folder to post? NOTE: If the POP folders appear under Local Folders on old PC, then look in the Mail\Local Folders folder and do screenshot of that as well (but only if there were supposed to be files there that are missing). Seeing that should help.

content:
re :The Windows Home has Thunderbird 128.10.oesr (32 bit) and the Windows Pro laptop has Thunderbird 128.9.2esr (64 bit).

You need to have the same version on both computers OR a newer one on the newer computer. So you need to download the current 'Thunderbird Extended Support Release' channel which is version 128.10.1

Where did you get the download installation for the new computer? If you used the Windows App Store then it does not use the same default location for profiles. Uninstall Thunderbird from new computer.

Get a download for 128.10.1 from the official webpage at this link: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Make sure to select preferred language and the Channel = Thunderbird Extended Support Release and OS = Windows.

This will then look in the correct location for profile. Please report back on what you now see.

content:
You get that redo profile error message because it sounds like you previously downloaded the 'Release' version which is a 138*

Do this:

Exit Thunderbird now this is important.

  • In windows search type: %Appdata%
  • Select the %Appdata% file folder option
  • Select 'Roaming' folder
  • Select 'Thunderbird' folder
  • Select 'Profiles' folder
  • Select the profile name folder which I think is 'ix708c3d.default' based on an earlier image you provided
  • Look for this file 'compatibility.ini' and delete it.

Then start up Thunderbird and report on results.

I'm glad all is now well. Once done, I encourage doing a backup now that all works. here is a repeat of the steps, just in case the computer crashes or is otherwise corrupted at a future date:

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there

content: Sorunun Thunderbird'den kaynaklandığını düşünmüyorum. E-posta hizmet sağlayıcınızdan (yani Güzel.net) kaynaklanma ihtimali daha yüksek. Hizmet sağlayıcınızın size sunduğu bir webmail arayüzü vardır, oradan e-posta göndermeyi denediğinizde sorun yaşıyor musunuz?
creator: maxcoder

content: Merhaba, Öncelikle vakit ayırıp yanıtladığınız için teşekkür ederim. Hizmet sağlayıcı ile ilk görüşmemde alan adımda SPF kaydının (ne olduğunu bilmiyorum) güncel olmadığını ve güncelleme yaptıklarını birkaç saat içinde sorunun çözüleceğini söylediler. Ertesi gün tekrar denediğimde yine gönderdiğim mailler (thunderbird üzerinden) karşı tarafa ve benim gmail hesabıma ulaşmadı. Ulaşmadığına dair herhangi bir bildirim almıyorum bu arada. Thunderbird içinde gönderilen klasörüne düşüyor mailler ama karşıya gitmiyor. İkinci görüşmemde web mail arayüzü üzerinden hem mail gönderdiler, hem de gönderdikleri maillere cevap yazdılar ve web mail arayüzünde herhangi bir problem yaşanmadı. Ben de daha sonra web mail arayüzünü kullandığımda problem yaşamadım. Bugün ise thunderbird üzerinde herhangi bir sorun yaşamıyorum ama acaba sorun SPF kaydı ile ilgili olabilir mi gerçekten? Vereceğiniz yanıt(lar) için şimdiden teşekkür ederim. Selamlar.

content: Evet, hatalı SPF kaydı böyle bir soruna yol açabilir.

content:
Although the procedure for copying profiles from one setup to a new one is supposed to work in principle, in practice it often creates problems like the one you reported. Trying to fix it usually takes much more time and effort than building a new profile. Which is why I always create new profiles for each annual release or new beta channel. This shouldn't be necessary when moving forward from the new monthly releases, 137, 138,..., but it's recommended for moving between, e.g., 128 ESR and 137 or 138.

First step is to create a new profile in 138 from Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles, add an IMAP account, and see if it works properly. The current profile is unaffected. If the new profile is working, local mail, address books and other data can be transferred from the old profile to the new. It might take a while the first time, but it's a valuable skill to acquire for future situations.

content:
It's frustrating when things don't make sense and help is not available. Try this:

  1. In Thunderbird, click on the "Help" menu.
  2. Click on "Troubleshooting information" in the "Help" menu.
  3. Look down the left column of the next window until you see "Profile Folder".
  4. Look across on the same row to the right column, where you will see a button labeled "Open Folder" or "Show in Finder" or something similar.
  5. Click on that button.
  6. You should then see a window with a folder name highlighted. Double-click on that folder to open it.
  7. Scan the contents of the folder for a file named "secmod.db". Do you see one?

content:
Hope, I don't know what is causing this problem or how to fix it. Let's hope that other people can help.

What version of Thunderbird are you using? Look under the Thunderbird menu and choose "About Thunderbird" to find out.

Are you using any anti-virus software?

My research finds actions that worked for some people with the same problem or a similar problem. You might try each of these one at a time.

1. Did you copy your Thunderbird profile from your main computer to your laptop? If you did, follow the directions above for accessing your profile folder. Find a file named pkcs11.txt. Delete it. Re-start Thunderbird.

2. Make sure that you know your password and/or have it written down. Return to where you verified that your password was saved. (See my screenshot above.) Delete your password. The next time you are asked for it, it might be saved successfully.

3. Start Windows in safe mode. (See instructions below.) Start Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode: "Help" menu, "Troubleshoot mode...", re-start Thunderbird. See if the problem goes away.

4. Follow the directions above for accessing your profile folder. Find the files named key3.db, cert8.db, and logins.json. Delete them. Re-start Thunderbird.

I am sorry that these things are complicated and I hope that you're doing OK.


How to start Windows in safe mode:

  1. Restart your computer.
  2. At the sign-in screen, hold down the Shift key and then click Power > Restart.
  3. After the computer restarts, you will see the Choose an Option screen. From here, you can select Troubleshoot > Advanced options > Startup Settings > Restart.
  4. Once your computer restarts, a list of options will appear. Press 4 or F4 to start in Safe Mode. If you need network access, press 5 or F5 for Safe Mode with Networking 1.

content:
Hi Magdalena,

Would you please say more about the history of your sent messages?

Have you always used IMAP accounts? Is your current account IMAP or POP?

Have you always keep sent messages in the sent folder or have you filed them in other server folders or local folders?

Have you always used the same e-mail account with the same e-mail service provider? Are you using the same e-mail account from that same e-mail service provider now?

When you got a new computer, did you transfer your Thunderbird profile from the old one? Do you have access to the data that was/is on your computer?

The cloud location that you seek is your e-mail service provider. You could log in to their Web site and see if the messages are there. But if you are accessing the same account from Thunderbird, and your messages are not in Thunderbird, then they are probably not on the server of your e-mail service provider either.

content:
To find out what kind of account you have, either 1) go to the "Thunderbird" menu, and click on "Account Settings", or 2) right click on the name of your account in the folder pane, and select "Settings".

Either way will get you to account settings. If you have more than one account, find the one that you are interested in on the left side of the window. Under its account name, click on "Server Settings". On the right side of the window, near the top, you will see either "IMAP Mail Server" or "POP Mail Server". Which do you see?

There is no reason why just using Thunderbird would mean that your e-mail service provider does not have your sent messages on its server. Is Thunderbird sending and receiving messages through that account successfully now? If it is, and you do not see the messages that you seek, then they are not on the server. (Because you could have a filter set or something else in Thunderbird that is interfering with message storage and display, the best way to confirm that the messages are not on the server is to sign in to webmail at your e-mail service provider and see what is in the sent mail folder.)

But you are asking about messages from two computers ago. When was the last time you saw those messages? Do you have access to that computer or to a copy of the data that was on it?
